Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Inverse-Consistent Determination of Effective Young's Modulus for Human Lung

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to use a combination of computational tools, radiological imaging and image processing methods to determine consistent effective elastic properties of human lung in a non-invasive manner. Such data, which do not currently exist, will enable accurate simulation of lung dynamics for targeted radiotherapy. Studies conducted under this award will reproduce lung geometry from computed tomography imaging, simulate by means of computational and image processing tools the airflow and spatial deformation of the lungs, and iteratively estimate the effective tissue elasticity for known values of airflow and deformation predicted using the computational tool. The estimated tissue elastic properties will be validated by comparison with manual landmark tracking established by a clinical expert.

This research, if successful, will significantly improve knowledge base on biomechanical properties of human tissue structures, and establish a property-performance relationship between the tissues and a wide range of clinical procedures. The approach could be used in a radiotherapy clinical workflow designed to track tumor motion and develop improved radiotherapy treatment that ultimately improves patient's treatment outcome and reduces overall cost. The knowledge gained from this study could be extended to other anatomical sites including biomechanical stress-induced plaque rupture in cardiovascular disease, estimation of cardiac tissue elasticity, and to address variations in imaging modality. This award is multidisciplinary, involving collaboration among scientists, engineers and clinicians at three institutions. The education plan focuses on nurturing the next generation of scientists and engineers by providing them with an opportunity to work on challenging problems of practical importance across disciplines. Undergraduate and graduate students will be engaged in the research, and will benefit from integration of research findings into classroom instruction and the multidisciplinary training in diverse fields.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

Computational organ dynamics that enables simulation of physics and physiology based organ deformation has been used for a variety of innovative applications such as virtual surgery and post- operative treatment predictions. Of particular significance are the simulation of three-dimensional lung dynamics and the treatment simulation for external beam lung radiotherapy. A key step towards the development of volumetric human lung models that could be used in radiotherapy to track tumor is the determination of the effective elastic property (specifically, the Young's modulus (YM)) associated with each location within the lung anatomy as well as the simulation of airflow inside the lungs. Prior to our project, such elastic property data were non-existent. The grant enabled the establishment for the first time, reliable data for the effective elastic property of human lung that is unique to each person. This goal was achieved by integrating the principles of medical imaging with computer simulation of the coupled airflow and spatial deformation of the lung during breathing, and using an inverse methodology to deduce the elastic property. The analysis considers the lung as a porous-elastic medium with non-uniform and spatially-varying property. The predicted tissue elastic properties are validated by iterative comparison with the values estimated from manual tracking of deformation of identified landmarks within the lung as established by a clinical expert.

Intellectual Merit

The project established for the first time, a reliable method for determining reliable and consistent values of the effective elastic property for human lungs through integration of theory, experiment and clinical practice. Specifically, it enabled the processing of images acquired on humans undergoing radiotherapy, reconstruction of the images into the true three-dimensional (3D) lung geometry, development and validation of bio-mechanical models of the lung, and integration of the patient-specific effective elasticity to model the spatial and transient lung deformation. The project thus delivered the strategies for intelligent estimation of the constitutive elastic property for human tissue. A total of 10 journal papers, four conference papers and a patent were produced from the research program. In addition, a number of software modules were developed including seamless coupling of  image registration and computational modeling, as well as a fusion algorithm. The project helped to develop a template for a multi-disciplinary approach integrating the principles of Biomechanics, Computational Modeling, and Radiology, to solve an important biomedical problem of fundamental and practical significance. By working together as a team, the collaborators were able to make advances that far exceeded the sum of their otherwise individual achievements. 

Broader Impact

The project had produced new knowledge base on the determination of the elastic property of human tissues, and established the property-performance relationship for tissues with potential variety of applications. The approach developed has been used in a scheme (patent pending) designed to track tumor motion for improved radiotherapy treatment that ultimately improves the patient's quality of life and reduces the overall treatment cost. The project was used to train a female graduate student to completion of a PhD. dissertation who has been employed at a major US medical company.  A second female student was partially supported towards a PhD. dissertation. Three undergraduate minority students were recruited to participate in the project as a means of introducing them to research at the early stages of their studies. The effort has stimulated their interest in applying to graduate schools and medical schools. The PI has gained knowledge of radiation oncology practice, image acquisition and image registration through the collaborative research with a Medical institution. The PI has introduced the principles used in the project into undergraduate class in Fluid Mechanics and a graduate class in Biofluid Mechanics at the University of Central Florida. The software infrastructure in the PI’s laboratory has been enhanced through acquisition of licenses for image processing and computational fluid dynamics modeling for this project. The participation of collaborators from Medical institutions has provided the graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to gain experience beyond their primary field of training.

Modified by: Olusegun J Ilegbusi

    Olusegun Ilegbusi

    Comparison of Predicted Spatial Deformation
  • Figure 4. Lung deformation along the (i) X axis, (ii) Y axis, and (iii) Z axis computed for the (a) right lung and (b) left lung using a multi-resolution optical flow algorithm.
    Olusegun Ilegbusi
    Public Domain
    Olusegun J Ilegbusi
    Lung Deformation from Optical Flow
  • Figure 5. Optimal lung deformation along the (a) X axis, (b) Y axis, and (c) Z axis computed for the left lung using Flow-Structure Interaction simulation.
    Olusegun Ilegbusi
    Public Domain
    Olusegun J Ilegbusi
    Optimal Lung Deformation
  • Figure 6. Differences in the displacement between the optimal lung deformation and the deformation observed in the 4D-CT DIR, shown for left and right lungs. The violet color coding represents less than 3 mm difference while blue and green represents greater than 3 mm difference.
    Olusegun Ilegbusi
    Copyrighted
    Olusegun J Ilegbusi
    Difference Between Optimal and Image-derived Lung Deformation

The participation of collaborators from Medical institutions has provided the graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to gain experience beyond their primary field of training.
